description: From Late Latin subsistentia (“substance, reality, in Medieval Latin also stability”), from Latin subsistens, present participle of subsistere (“to continue, subsist”). See subsist.

examples: the human nature loseth its proper subsistence , and is assumed into the subsistence of the divine nature

entries.meaning: The act of maintaining oneself at a minimum level.

examples: the subsistence of qualities in bodies

entries.meaning: Something (food, water, money, etc.) that is required to stay alive.
examples: His viceroy could only propose to himself a comfortable subsistence out of the plunder of his province.

entries.meaning: (theology) Embodiment or personification or hypostasis of an underlying principle or quality.
